results.title: With Grandma
results.creator_credit: Francoise Hartmann and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The initial fears of leaving mum and dad behind quickly disappear as dress ups, photographs of grandma as a young girl, games, special food and stories appear that only a grandma can provide as the generation gap between a young girl and an older woman is bridged. A lyrical look, without words, at the shared experiences of a young girl visiting with her grandmother.

results.creator_credit: Barbara Doran, Kent Martin and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An insider’s look at the business of romantic fiction writing at Harlequin Publishing. Writers, editors, designers and the male models who pose for the book covers discuss their own roles and the expectations of the readers. Readers discuss the appeal of the romantic genre, and argue its literary merit. Features interviews with writers Barbara Cartland, Virginia Henley and Heather Graham.

results.title: Through a blue lens
results.creator_credit: Veronica Alice Mannix, Gillian Darling Kovanic and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Six Vancouver policemen have formed the Odd Squad - a team of officers dedicated to capturing the thoughts and feelings of drug addicts in Vancouver’s Downtown Eastside as a means of preventing drug use by young people. They initially began with a camera that captured vignettes with an anti drug message, then moved onto a movie camera so that addicts could tell a story in their own words. Most of the addicts are willing to take part in the anti drug war in the only way they can - by courageously using themselves as examples. Through the process the Odd Squad develop tenuous relationships with the addicts and discover that the people they meet had lives prior to their addiction. This powerful educational tool contains coarse language and graphic scenes. Preview is recommended.

results.title: Mother of many children
results.creator_credit: Alanis Obomsawin and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film is an album of Native womanhood, portraying a proud egalitarian matriarchal society that for centuries has been pressured to adopt different standards and customs. All of the women featured share a belief in the importance of tradition as a source of strength in the face of change. Ethnographic documentation of Native Canadian ‘American’ post colonialisation which includes documented accounts of the ‘stolen generation’ in Native American tribes and personal accounts of racial discrimination. Directed, written, produced and narrated by Alanis Obomsawin. (Awards: San Francisco; Dieppe)
